snippet.textDisplay: @Angeal Astral Well all in all it is a high quality game, with for the time, great graphics, an excellent soundtrack and  sympathetic core characters. Main complaints about it are usually the high character count (which you can't collect in one playthrough), a sometimes repetitive nature (Fort Dragonia multiple playthroughs) and the little connection to the more popular predecessor. I still recommend playing Chrono Trigger first so you can appreciate these connections to the fullest.
snippet.textOriginal: @Angeal Astral Well all in all it is a high quality game, with for the time, great graphics, an excellent soundtrack and  sympathetic core characters. Main complaints about it are usually the high character count (which you can't collect in one playthrough), a sometimes repetitive nature (Fort Dragonia multiple playthroughs) and the little connection to the more popular predecessor. I still recommend playing Chrono Trigger first so you can appreciate these connections to the fullest.

snippet.textDisplay: I feel like I need to give this game more of a chance. I was never really into it all that much. I absolutely love the music, that much is for sure. Yasunori Mitsuda is one of my favorite composers of all time, if not my absolute favorite, but in terms of the game itself, I didn't enjoy what I played. However, I'm nearing the end of my first full playthrough of Chrono Trigger now after years of playing it but never beating it, so maybe when I finally put that game to rest, I can try to get back into this one at full force, because I definitely want to see how the story plays out.
snippet.textOriginal: I feel like I need to give this game more of a chance. I was never really into it all that much. I absolutely love the music, that much is for sure. snippet.textDisplay:
There was a period of time, stretching between FF6 on the SNES to Skies of Arcadia on the Dreamcast when J-rpgs were just so damn good! Grandia, FF-Anything, Chrono-Cross, Shining Force 3, and a ton of others that I have for my Playstation1. 
Not being critical of current stuff, but damn they just kicked so much butt back then, devs were in the zone!
snippet.textOriginal:

Not being critical of current stuff, but damn they just kicked so much butt back then, devs were in the zone!

snippet.textDisplay: It's partly because games are so expensive to make now, actually. The developers still care just as much, but the money needs to come from somewhere, and the people who give the money often don't know much about or care much about games. They call the shots even though they have no idea what they're doing, and pull "mass appeal" from popular games, trying to jam mechanics it into places that they don't fit. They can also change stuff at the last minute, which I imagine wreaks havoc on development.
snippet.textOriginal: It's partly because games are so expensive to make now, actually. The developers still care just as much, but the money needs to come from somewhere, and the people who give the money often don't know much about or care much about games. snippet.textDisplay:
That's because back then, Developers actually poured their hearts and souls into their work most of the time instead of just creating mindless shovelwear and graphical revamps of what they've already made. Yes, that still exists today. But, it's a little less apparent nowadays. Though you can find games that still have the hearts and souls of their developers in them. Games that looked as though they were painstakingly made.

Though that era also had that, there was a bit more quality control too.

snippet.textDisplay:
What was the start of all this?
   When did the cogs of fate begin to turn?
   
   Perhaps it is impossible to grasp that answer now,
   From deep within the flow of time...
   
   But, for a certainty, back then,
   We loved so many, yet hated so much,
   We hurt others and were hurt ourselves...
   
   Yet even then, we ran like the wind,
   Whilst our laughter echoed,
   Under cerulean skies...

snippet.textDisplay: There are things called "Let's Play", which allow you to enjoy a video game without playing it, if gameplay is so boring to you. Secondly, any game can be boring if you play it wrong. I play the MGS series, for example, aiming for a No Kill/No Alert game every time, and it's satisfying to see that Big Boss rank at the end. Or Super Mario World, I speed-rush every exit with minimal Cape/Yoshi usage, just for fun's sake. That said, a good plot makes you care about why you are playing, not how.
